title: Gratitude & Appreciation
description: Celebrate what you value most about each other.

questions.text: What quality of mine do you most appreciate?
choices: My kindness and caring nature
My sense of humor and playfulness
My strength and resilience
My honesty and authenticity

therapeutic.rationale: Expressing appreciation for specific qualities strengthens bonds and validates identity. Kindness appreciation values nurturing; humor appreciation values playfulness; strength appreciation values resilience; honesty appreciation values authenticity; support appreciation values reliability. Knowing which of your qualities your partner most values reinforces that aspect of your identity.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different appreciated qualities reveal what each of you sees as the other's core gift. Share what you most appreciate—your partner may not know which quality shines brightest to you.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared appreciated qualities suggest this trait is central to the relationship. It's a defining characteristic that matters to you both.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What quality in your partner do you most appreciate? Have you told them recently? What would it mean to them to hear it?

questions.text: What do I do that makes you feel most loved?
choices: How I listen when you talk
Small daily gestures of care
Physical affection and touch
Making you a priority in my life

therapeutic.rationale: The actions that make our partner feel loved become our most important behaviors. Active listening shows attention; daily gestures show consistent caring; physical affection shows bodily love; defending shows loyalty; prioritizing shows choice. Knowing what makes your partner feel loved helps you do more of it intentionally.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different love-feeling actions mean you're each touched by different behaviors. Tell your partner what they do that makes you feel most loved—they should keep doing it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared love-feeling actions mean the same behaviors register as love for you both. You're aligned on what loving behavior looks like.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does your partner do that makes you feel most loved? When did they last do it? Have you told them how much it matters?

questions.text: What about our relationship am I most grateful for?
choices: The safety and security we've built
How much fun we have together
The depth of our emotional bond
Our ability to grow and learn together

therapeutic.rationale: Gratitude for relationship aspects reinforces their value. Safety gratitude appreciates security; fun gratitude appreciates joy; emotional-bond gratitude appreciates intimacy; growth gratitude appreciates development; presence gratitude appreciates the fundamental gift of partnership. Expressing gratitude for the relationship itself strengthens commitment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different gratitude focuses reveal different relationship values. You may be grateful for safety while your partner is grateful for growth. Both are true—express your specific gratitude.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared gratitude focus means you value the same aspect of your relationship. Protect and nurture what you're both grateful for.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What about your relationship are you most grateful for? When was the last time you expressed this gratitude? What would change if you expressed it more often?

questions.text: What's something you've done that I'll never forget?
choices: How you supported me through something hard
A romantic gesture that surprised me
A sacrifice you made for us
Showing me a side of yourself no one else sees

therapeutic.rationale: Memorable moments become relationship touchstones that define the partnership's story. Support memories show reliability; romantic gestures show effort; sacrifices show commitment; presence shows devotion; vulnerability-sharing shows trust. These become the stories couples tell about why they love each other.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different unforgettable moments reveal different defining points in your relationship story. Share your moment—your partner may not know it was so significant.
therapeutic.whenSame: A shared unforgettable moment becomes a cornerstone of your relationship narrative. Return to this story when you need to remember your bond.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What has your partner done that you'll never forget? Have you told them recently how much it meant? What made it so memorable?

questions.text: How do I prefer to receive appreciation from you?
choices: Hearing it in words
Seeing it in your actions
Physical affection that shows it
Quality time together

therapeutic.rationale: How we receive appreciation matters as much as giving it. Verbal receivers need words; action-observers need demonstrated appreciation; physical receivers need touch-expressed gratitude; time receivers need invested presence; public receivers need external acknowledgment. Expressing appreciation in your partner's preferred form ensures it lands.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different receiving styles mean your appreciation may not land as intended. The verbal receiver may not register action-appreciation; the public receiver may feel invisible without external acknowledgment. Show appreciation in your partner's preferred form.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared receiving styles mean your appreciation will naturally connect. You'll both feel valued through the same expressions.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you most like to receive appreciation? Does your partner express it this way? What would help them know what works for you?
